ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned about how queerness is religious and different queer theory. I think there was less focus on how religion is queer than I expected, but I still really enjoyed the material and discussions.
I gained the ability to think critically about the intersection of queerness and religion (Christianity specifically)
I learned about queer, religious and feminist theory alongside great classmates!!!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed the student presentations and break-out rooms when used to spark discussion and also review some of the denser texts.

Strengths: readings are super interesting, discussion was good when it was going, and the ~vibe~ of the class was always friendly

Weaknesses: depending on the week, sometimes there was just too much reading on top of weekly reading responses. But by the end Prof Mallete seemed to realize it was a lot and allowed us up to 3 skips, so I assume next time will be different.

Strengths include the interesting subject matter and the freedom to explore projects of our choice for our assignments. A weakness was that the seminar felt very quiet over zoom, and that some weeks' material felt like just intro WGSS material without the connection to religion that I had hoped for.

This course was awesomea super interesting exploration of queerness and religion. One thing that might be helpful is including more introductory readings on theologylots of students had prior knowledge of queerness and the readings were more queer-focused than religion-focused, so it was hard to get started with the theology side.

Strengths: Prof. Mallette! Very sweet and brings multimedia presentations (art and videos) to class that compliment the readings 
Weakness: A few of the articles were very dense and it was tough reading through them, but most were amazing + scholars I hadn't read before

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Perhaps more time to check in with the general class before proceeding with the day's agenda. In times of covid, I've found the "check in" at the beginning of a virtual seminar really beneficial.

I really liked break out rooms! It was a great way to get to know the other students in the class better, air out confusion or frustration with particular texts, and hear and process ideas and insights. The mid-class breaks were also very helpful!

Little was really integrated into this course since it is a seminar and remained a seminar, only virtually. It definitely lost some of the natural flow via Zoom. However, I felt the prof was very understanding and compassionate during this time.
The multimedia aspect succeeded and we also got 5min breaks because it was a 2 hour class

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Wendy is amazing! The material is really fascinating, and if some of it intimidates you, you are not alone! Wendy is great about bringing in videos and photos to help provide context and break up some of the denser reading. I'm so grateful to have read all of the pieces on this syllabus. While you will have to devote time to really dive into and understand some of the readings, it will be worth it.

Yes! It wasn't quite what I expected off of the title "Queer Religion"it was kind of more a queer theory survey course in relation to some religious theological concepts and readings, and the religion aspect sometimes fell behind, but still well worth it.
I would recommend this course to people interested in queerness and Christianity, but this class is not a gut! There is lots of reading so be prepared for that!
YES! overall great course and you think about the intersections between queerness and religion
I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. The subject material is thrilling and Prof. Mallette is an excellent instructor.
